Verification of the claim on the World B: s website: The expert confirms that the claim made by Ben Swann regarding the purchase of COVID-19 testing kits in 2017 and 2018 on the World Bank's World Integrated Trade Solution (WITS) website is true. The expert mentions that the tables can be found on the WITS website and provides archived versions as evidence.
Multiple sources and languages: The expert notes that similar claims about the purchase of COVID-19 test kits in different years and with different product codes were found on various social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, and in different languages such as English, Arabic, and French. This indicates that the claim has gained attention and has been discussed in multiple contexts.
Explanation from the World Bank: The expert mentions that the World Bank, when asked about the claim, provided an explanation via email. The World Bank clarified that the products mentioned in the WITS database with the label "COVID-19" were actually medical equipment that had been used for other purposes but gained importance during the pandemic. The World Bank also mentioned the list of Harmonized System (HS) codes created by the World Customs Organization (WCO) to track critical products related to COVID-19.
Identification of specific product codes: The expert highlights the specific product codes mentioned in the claim (382200, 300215, and 902780) and explains their significance. The expert states that code 382200 corresponds to diagnostic reagents based on polymerase chain reaction (PCR) nucleic acid test, code 300215 tracks diagnostic reagents based on immunological reactions, and code 902780 helps track instruments used in clinical laboratories for in vitro diagnosis. This information further supports the authenticity of the claim.
